head.title: The Encounter at the Gas Pump: Other Views

hedline.hl1: The Encounter at the Gas Pump: Other Views

abstract.p: Mary E Robinson letter on Peter Applebome's July 2 column on how to react to black man playing loud and offensive rap music at gas station pump holds issue is manners, not race (S)

block.p: Dozens of readers responded to Peter Applebome's July 2 column. Here is a sampling of their reactions.

The issue is manners, no matter where you may be! It really isn't about race, it is about class. We avoid the word in today's society. Let's face it, bad manners do not have any color. Unfortunately, they exist in all geographic areas.
Dozens of readers responded to Peter Applebome's July 2 column. Here is a sampling of their reactions.

The issue is manners, no matter where you may be! It really isn't about race, it is about class. We avoid the word in today's society. Let's face it, bad manners do not have any color. Unfortunately, they exist in all geographic areas.

I really do not perceive any dilemma here, maybe just a tinge of racism, ''classism,'' and geographic snobbery. What you described would be considered offensive by most people, not just white, upper-income northern Westchester residents.

What would I do? Why would I do or not do it? I would close the windows of my car, complete my business a quickly as possible and explain to my child/grandchild how that incident was a graphic example of inconsiderate behavior, better known as bad manners.
Coincidentally, I am a woman of color, the mother of a correction officer and a resident of Westchester.
